problems.title: NBHM 2005 - \int_{\Gamma } \frac{z \mathrm{d} z}{(z - 1)^4}
problems.problem:
Let $\Gamma $ be the circle in the complex plane with centre at $z = 1$ and of radius unity. Evaluate 
    \[
        \int_{\Gamma } \frac{z \mathrm{d} z}{(z - 1)^4}.
    \]
problems.hint: • Use Cauchy's integral formula.
problems.solution:
We will use Cauchy's integral formula to evaluate the integral over the circle $|z-1| = 1$ \[ \int_{\Gamma } \frac{z \mathrm{d} z}{(z - 1)^4}. \] By Cauchy's integral formula, \begin{align*} f^{(n)}(a) = \frac{n!}{2\pi \iota } \int_{\gamma } \frac{f(z)}{(z - a)^{n+1}} \mathrm{d} z, \end{align*} where $\gamma $be the circle $\vert z - z_0 \vert = r$, oriented counterclockwise and $a$ is any point in the interior of the disc $\vert z - z_0 \vert \leq r.$
Here $f(z) = z$, the disc is $\vert z - 1 \vert \leq 1$ and the point $a = 1$ which is in the interior of the disc. So, by Cauchy's integral formula, a \begin{align*} \int_{\Gamma } \frac{z \mathrm{d} z}{(z - 1)^4} & = \frac{2\pi \iota }{3!} \left[ \frac{\mathrm{d}^3}{\mathrm{d}z^3} (z) \right]_{z = 1} = 0. \end{align*}

problems.title: NBHM - 2005 - Pick out the functions from the following list which are analytic in C
problems.problem:
Pick out the functions from the following list which are analytic in $\mathbb{C} :$
  1. $f(z) = \vert z \vert ^2$
  2. $f(z) = \bar{z} $
  3. $f(z) = \text{ Re } (z)$.
problems.hint: • Apply the Cauchy-Riemann equations.
problems.solution:
Recall that if a complex function \[ f(z) = u(x,y) + \iota v(x,y), \] is analytic in a region $D$, then it must satisfy the Cauchy-Riemann equations, that is, \begin{align*} \frac{\partial u}{\partial x} = \frac{\partial v}{\partial y} \text{ and } \frac{\partial u}{\partial y} = - \frac{\partial v}{\partial x} \text{ on } D. \end{align*} This is equivalent to say that $\frac{\partial f}{\partial \bar{z} } = 0 $ on $D$.
  1. The given function is $f(z) = \vert z \vert ^2 = z \bar{z}$. The function is not analytic in $\mathbb{C} $ as \[ \frac{\partial f}{\partial \bar{z} } = z \neq 0 \text{ on } \mathbb{C} . \]
  2. For the function $f(z) = \bar{z} $, \[ \frac{\partial f}{\partial \bar{z} } = 1 \neq 0 \text{ on } \mathbb{C}, \] and hence it is not analytic on $\mathbb{C} $.
  3. Recall that $\text{ Re } (z) = \frac{z + \bar{z}}{2}$, which is also not analytic on $\mathbb{C} $ as \[ \frac{\partial f}{\partial \bar{z} } (\text{ Re } (z)) = \frac{1}{2} \neq 0. \]

problems.title: NBHM 2005 - Is sin^2 z + cos^2 z = 1
problems.problem:
Pick out the statements which are true:
  1. $\vert \sin z \vert \leq 1$ for all $z \in \mathbb{C} $.
  2. $\sin ^2 z + \cos ^2 z = 1$ for all $z \in \mathbb{C} $.
  3. $\sin z = \frac{e^{\iota z} - e^{-\iota z}}{2}$ for all $z \in \mathbb{C} $.
problems.hint:
• Apply Liouville's theorem.
  • Note that $e^{\iota x} = \cos x + \iota \sin x$.
problems.solution:
1. Since $\sin z$ is an entire function, so using Liouville's theorem it can not be bounded as bounded entire function must be constant. Thus, the statement is FALSE.
  2. Again we will use Liouville's theorem. Since $\sin z$ and $\cos z$ both are entire functions, the function $\sin ^2 z + \cos ^2 z $ also be n entire function and hence it can not be bounded. Thus, $\sin ^2 z + \cos ^2 = 1$ is FALSE.
  3. Note that for $z = x + \iota y$, \begin{align*} e^{z} = e^x (\cos y + \iota \sin y) \implies e^{\iota x} = \cos x + \iota \sin x . \end{align*} Thus we have \begin{align*} e^{\iota z} & = \cos z + \iota \sin (z) \text{ and } e^{-\iota z} = \cos z - \iota \sin z. \end{align*} Thus, \begin{align*} \cos z = \frac{e^{\iota z} + e^{-\iota z}}{2} \text{ and } \sin z = \frac{e^{\iota z} - e^{-\iota z}}{2\iota }. \end{align*} Thus, the statement is FALSE.
